Media: The New York Times
Review: This latest musical adapted from one of Disney<U+2019>s popular movies defied my dour expectations...<U+201C>Aladdin<U+201D> has an infectious and only mildly syrupy spirit. Not to mention enough baubles, bangles and beading to keep a whole season of <U+201C>RuPaul<U+2019>s Drag Race<U+201D> contestants in runway attire.

Media: Theatermania
Review: You're going to have a great time at Aladdin, despite its conflict-starved filler of a book. But are you really going for the dramaturgy  No, you're going to see sexy actors sing and dance while performing magic tricks. In that regard, Aladdin delivers in abundance.

Media: New York Post
Review: James Monroe Iglehart injects liveliness and humor into a merely tolerable stage adaptation of Disney<U+2019>s animated hit 'Aladdin'.

Media: Variety
Review: This super-costly extravaganza doesn't do justice to the movie, or to the spirit of the late Howard Ashman.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: Aside from the tonic of Iglehart<U+2019>s djinn, however, Aladdin is short on magic.

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: Score Aladdin a considerable win for Disney, likely to fill the New Amsterdam with happy crowds for seasons to come. Better than Little Mermaid, Aida and Tarzan, though not exactly a knockout.

Media: New York Theater
Review: In Aladdin, the new Disney musical on Broadway, the genie grants theatergoers the first of their wishes <U+2013> to be entertained.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: Everything else in Aladdin is, like the endlessly expansive desert in which it's set, dusty and unwelcoming.

Media: The Wall Street Journal
Review: It's not nearly as good as the movie, but it does have a terrific star, super-duper sets and sensational special effects.

Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: While it doesn't rival the imagination or innovation of  The Lion King,
Review (Don't): the show's ebullient comic spirit should make it a popular hit. It's not the most sophisticated entertainment, but the target demographic won't mind at all.

Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: So why is Aladdin a bit of a chore  Even the best of what the writers offer doesn<U+2019>t seem to stick very long; if it weren<U+2019>t for Nicholaw<U+2019>s merciless flogging, you feel the story would simply evaporate in the desert heat.

Media: New York Daily News
Review: The show is as colorful as the Crayola 64 box, and as tirelessly energetic as a toddler, but it also feels canned. While burning through wishes, you should ask for the musical to have a lot more heart. The absence is glaring, given that Disney excels at tugging at tickers and then making them melt.

Media: Chicago Tribune
Review: Much of the show just skedaddles along, hitting the plot points without enough oomph.

Media: Newsday
Review: The carpet flies, kids, and it's awesome...Such awesomeness, of course, is to be expected from  Aladdin.  But what's a whole new world, as the song promises, is the almost modest, down-to-earth human scale of director-choreographer Casey  Nicholaw's big, cheerful production -- an enjoyable throwback to old-time musical comedy.

Media: NorthJersey.com
Review: The show is a flavorless rehash of what's been done much better before.

Media: CitiTour
Review: It may not be completely out of this world, but it will absolutely lift your spirits.

Media: Theater Pizzazz
Review: Disney<U+2019>s latest offering at the New Amsterdam Theatre, is simply . . .<U+00A0> maaaahvelous! The costumes, the sets, the kitsch and comedic fun made me feel like a kid again.

Media: The Washington Post
Review: This version of 'Aladdin' will doubtless keep your kiddies happy; for adults, one would like to press Iglehart in the cause of conjuring a desert kingdom of richer enchantments.

Media: USA Today
Review: It's genie-us! 'Aladdin' rubs you the right way

Media: Financial Times (UK)
Review: Disney wanted something it could market not only to the parents-with-children crowd but also to date-night couples looking for a few laughs. Wish granted.

Media: Reflections in the Light
Review: This larger-than-life, stunning visual production that sparkles on many levels really is a treat

Media: Time Magazine
Review: Aladdin is frisky and fun, another demonstration of Disney professionalism.

Media: Stage Opinion
Review: This big, busy, splashy family entertainment fits right in; it feels a bit generic, but it certainly delivers in terms of sheer eye-popping spectacle, and is sure to run and run.

Media: New Jersey Newsroom
Review: A lively and good-looking ensemble expertly undulates through the sometimes zany choreography.

Media: Stu on Broadway
Review: Aladdin, while charming and fun, lacks the enchantment and savviness of Disney<U+2019>s most notable theatrical productions.

Media: ChrisCaggiano.com
Review: From where I sat, Aladdin was diverting, to be sure, but ultimately uninspired...it feels like a passable summer-stock production with a Broadway budget. The look is lush and colorful, but the production itself is sluggish and pedestrian.

Media: Perez Hilton
Review: Everything about Aladdin is a win win WIN!

Media: Entertainment Weekly
Review: This is one of the better Disney stage musicals, complete with several eye-popping production numbers

Media: ThisbroadSway
Review: The stage is alive from beginning to end. It<U+2019>s a spectacle of lights and sound...Iglehart was a most lovable Genie, and the audience ate him up. It<U+2019>s not often you see a standing ovation partially through the 1st act, but this stuff is so good. The audience was so energized, that the whole theatre was shaking...So there you have it...Don<U+2019>t walk<U+2026>.RUN.

Media: WNBC
Review: The musical comedy is all about one character: the Genie. But that is not the only thing worth talking about. From <U+201C>Arabian Nights<U+201D> to <U+201C>Prince Ali,<U+201D> Nicholaw uses his multicultural ensemble flawlessly, unraveling layers to each number that surprise and wonder. You<U+2019>ll also marvel at Gregg Barnes<U+2019> stunning costumes, rich in jewel-tones, feathers and sparkle.

Media: AndyGram
Review: The reason Aladdin works so well on the stage is that it always seemed destined for it. I'm happy to report that it makes the transition to stage seamlessly in a lavish and magical production that the whole family will enjoy.

Media: Catholic Transcript
Review: Mainly, this Aladdin is F-U-N because it was so craftily assembled. Aladdin is a treat for the eye and ear.

Media: Broadway Voice
Review: Enchanting but not extreme, magical without unnecessary fireworks, jaw-dropping without having to fly over the audience.

Review: Here<U+2019>s the thing: this production is a huge and colorful spectacle, but ultimately, I thought it lacked heart <U+2013> the heart that I feel is deeply a  part of the movie...I don<U+2019>t think the show goes much deeper than the glitzy surface.

Media: Clever, Overrated, Entertaining, Fluffy  Dan 6098
Review: See it if You like sitting with children who fidget. A plot that goes nowhere till the Genies's Cave. You like your emotions manipulated by Disney.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You don't like seeing a chorus that are tired of doing the show and are walking...the Genies' words are important to you, his diction stinks=Also This show manipulates emotions unlike any I've seen before. The next day I realized what I saw was not so wonderful as I felt it was when I left the theatre. The chorus are bored, and are still collecting checks weekly. The leads (still the original) are 'fresh' but the Genie knows his words and says them so quickly he steps on his own jokes and understanding him is impossible...maybe he wanted to get home early that night. The theatre is worth the price of admission, and was the best part of the evening for me. Beware if children are next to you, or infront of you...parents seem to think anything they do is precious, even if they are preventing you from seeing (climbing on the seats) or hearing (talking out loud) what you payed money to see...the children were frequently bored, the performance should have entertained them so that they were attentive...didn't happen. I'm almost ashamed to say I saw this show...I've seen better, and expected more on Broadway....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Beautiful costumes and set, as well as strong performances overall. I saw the show with Joshua Dela Cruz as Aladdin instead of Adam Jacobs, and I was very impressed with his vocal range and overall performance. The Genie definitely was one of the strongest performers, and seeing Jonathan Freeman, original voice of Jafar in the movie, in the show was a huge bonus. Unfortunately, the actress playing Jasmine was not quite as strong as the rest of the cast. Her delivery seemed very stiff, and her singing got really pitchy at several points. Review: See it if You like funny dialogue, dazzling numbers, memorable tunes.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You don't enjoy cheerful, buoyant, Disney shows.=Also How could anyone fill Robin Williams's curly-toed genie shoes  Well, James Monroe Iglehart makes the part his own! His Tony-award-winning performance is delightful, his singing is extraordinary, and his improv skills are hilarious. Jonathan Freeman, who created the role of Jafar in the Disney movie, brings a Cyril Richard level of vocal acrobatics to the part on Broadway. Aladdin and Jasmin are charming. The score by Ashman, Menken, Rice, and Beguilen beguiles. The flying carpet scene enchants on a starry stage that feels like it extends all the way to Agrabah. This is a show for the whole family, but it would also make a wonderful date night. The New Amsterdam theater is an additional star in the show. Don't miss the exquisitely restored lounge on the lower level....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=
